head.title: If Thou Hast Lost a Friend
head.firstline: If thou hast lost a friend

poem.body:
If thou hast lost a friend, By hard or hasty word, Go, call him to thy heart again; Let pride no more be heard. Remind him of those happy days, Too beautiful to last; Ask, if a word should cancel years Of truth and friendship past! Oh! if thou'st lost a friend, By hard or hasty word, Go, call him to thy heart again; Let pride mo more be heard.
Oh! tell him, from thy thought The light of joy hath fled; That, in thy sad and silent breast, Thy lonely heart seems dead; That mount and vale, each path ye trod, By morn or evening dim, Reproach you with their frowning gaze, And ask your soul for him. Then, if thou'st lost a friend, By hard or hasty word, Go, call him to thy heart again; Let pride no more be heard.
